title: And When I Die
text:
"And When I Die" is a song written by American singer and songwriter <a href="Laura%20Nyro">Laura Nyro</a>. It was first recorded by the folk group <a href="Peter%2C%20Paul%20and%20Mary">Peter, Paul and Mary</a> in 1966. Nyro released her own version on her debut album "<a href="More%20Than%20a%20New%20Discovery">More Than a New Discovery</a>" in February 1967.
The song is best known for the next version, recorded by the <a href="Jazz%20fusion">jazz-rock</a> group <a href="Blood%2C%20Sweat%20%26amp%3B%20Tears">Blood, Sweat & Tears</a> in late 1968. This recording reached No. 2 on the US <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">"Billboard" Hot 100</a> and became a Gold record. In the US, it was kept from #1 by the <a href="double%20A-side">double A-side</a> "<a href="Come%20Together">Come Together</a>"/"<a href="Something%20%28Beatles%20song%29">Something</a>" by <a href="The%20Beatles">The Beatles</a>. "And When I Die" also reached No. 1 in Canada, in December 1969.
Lyrics.
The song gives a positive outlook about death, stating, in the chorus, "And when I die / and when I'm gone / there'll be one child born, in this world / to carry on / to carry on."
History.
"And When I Die" was one of the first songs recorded by Nyro, when she was 17 years old. She then sold the song to folk group <a href="Peter%2C%20Paul%20and%20Mary">Peter, Paul and Mary</a> for $5000, who then recorded the song for their sixth studio album "<a href="The%20Peter%2C%20Paul%20and%20Mary%20Album">The Peter, Paul and Mary Album</a>".
The song appeared on the <a href="Blood%2C%20Sweat%20%26amp%3B%20Tears%20%28Blood%2C%20Sweat%20%26amp%3B%20Tears%20album%29">self-titled second album</a> by Blood, Sweat & Tears. It was the third single from the album, peaking at #2 on the <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">"Billboard" Hot 100</a>; the album's previous two singles had also stalled at #2 on the same chart.
The BS&T arrangement is very different from previous versions. It was also released as an album version and an edited single version. The album version features two instrumental portions, one featuring an <a href="RMI%20Electra%20Piano">RMI Electra Piano</a>, and the other featuring horns and <a href="temple%20blocks">temple blocks</a>, like a <a href="Western%20music%20%28North%20America%29">western</a> cowboy song. Also, the pauses between the choruses and the other two verses are longer than on the edited version.
